topic.title: HP Helion OpenStack 2.0: Adding an Object Storage Daemon (OSD) Node

body.p: The page describes the procedure to add a new OSD Node to an existing Ceph cluster.

p.b: Procedure to add a new OSD Node

body.p:
Perform the following steps to add a new OSD Node to an existing Ceph cluster:
Login to the deployer node.
Edit ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/servers.yml to define a new OSD node as shown below:- id: con-0004 ip-addr: 192.168.10.9 role: ROLE-OSDReplace the id and ip-addr in the above snippet with appropriate values.
Commit your configuration to the local git repo, as follows: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible git add -A git commit -m "Added OSD node <node-id>"Replace the <node-id> in the commit message with appropriate value (example: con-004).
Execute the following command:cd ~/helion/hos/ansible/ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost cobbler-deploy.yml
Run the following command, which will reimage all the nodes using PXE.ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost bm-reimage.yml
Run the configuration processor:ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Use the playbook below to create a deployment directory: ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
Run your "verb_host" commands using the following steps:
cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts guard-deployment.yml ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts osconfig-run.yml ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts ceph-deploy.yml
Therefore, the new OSD node is deployed in an existing ceph cluster.
Verify the newly added OSD node
From the deployer node, execute the following command:$ceph --cluster ceph osd treeIf the Ceph cluster name is different than the default (i.e. ceph), you need to modify the above command accordingly.
When you execute the above command the hostname of the newly added OSD must appear in the output, if the OSD node is successfully added to the existing ceph cluster.
